title: Incorrect keyboard input when using "AltGr" key.
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.39.1
- OS Version: Microsoft Windows (Pro) Version 1903 (OS Build 10.18362.418)
- PowerShell Version: 5.1

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VSCode
2. Open a Terminal
3. Make keyboard keys input combination of "AltGr + 2 then Space" or "AltGr + 7 then Space"
4. You get the standard key (unexpected) plus the AltGr key (expected)

This happens on an AZERTY keyboard (a Surface Type Cover). I am not able to confirm if this happens on QWERTY too.

On AZERTY keyboards, the keys "2" and "7" consist in 3 characters:
- Keyboard key "2": é (standard) + 2 (shift) + ~ (AltGr+Space)
- Keyboard key "7": è (standard) + 7 (shift) + ` (AltGr+Space)

Note: **This dysfunction only affects PowerShell through VSCode. Code workspace is not affected. And native PowerShell also behaves perfectly.**

These keys are quite intensively used. Any solution would be appreciated.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: **Yes**

See https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/82253#issuecomment-541528757 for reasoning.

title: Fix #82200 - "Preserve Case" button in search viewlet is not tabbable
body:
@roblourens  , Added the tab functionality for the preserve case button in order to fix #82200.

Whatever `onRegexKeyDown` was doing before is now being done in `onPreserveCaseKeyDown` and `onRegexKeyDown` only makes the preserve case to get focussed.

body: Issue Type: Bug When zoomed in 3 times (Ctrl++), if you go to File->Preferences, the Preferences submenu appears with a scroll bar on the right side and the last two items on the list are not visible. title: Source control - staged changes tree view inconsistent
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.39.1
- OS Version: Darwin x64 18.7.0

Steps to Reproduce:

## Setup:
1. In an active git repo, with existing commits.
2. Move a file between directories.
3. Set Source control view to tree view.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14353068/66730497-c9c90900-ee84-11e9-824c-2b59f88e2c35.png)

## Errors: (begin all at stage 3 above)
### Staging the addition first:
4a1. Stage the addition (untracked) part of the change: (displayed correctly)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14353068/66730534-f7ae4d80-ee84-11e9-9073-a88fb59cfbd5.png)
4a2. Stage the deletion part of the change:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14353068/66730548-0a288700-ee85-11e9-8bc0-300618960149.png)
Note that the Staged Changes tab is expanded in the image above. The **1** change badge is displayed, but the change(s) themselves are not.

### Staging all changes at once:
4b1. Stage all changes.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14353068/66730595-61c6f280-ee85-11e9-815c-2c77abc321ce.png)
Note that only the addition is shown, with no type badge.
4b2. Unstage the file (by clicking the `-` next to the file)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14353068/66730651-a0f54380-ee85-11e9-9dec-6656de8d45d5.png)
The deletion is now displayed correctly

### Staging the deletion first:
4c1. Stage the deletion - displays correctly. (same state as 4b2)
4c2. Stage the addition - displays correctly, with the Renamed badge.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14353068/66730848-af902a80-ee86-11e9-96d0-fc3198def40d.png)
4c3. Unstage the folder or the file change.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14353068/66730884-ed8d4e80-ee86-11e9-96f4-1e697892e1a1.png)
Only the Addition (Untracked) is unstaged. This is (for me) unexpected behaviour, but does not differ from the way the source control view acts on any Renamed file. I would expect, since I'm acting on a Renamed (ie the Untracked and the Deleted file(s)) that both actions would return to the Changes tab.

4a and 4b seem to be bugs caused by order of operation. 4c3 is, I guess, a feature request, but closely related.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Ability to more effectively run unit tests for extension development
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
The vscode-test package allows you to run integration tests where you launch the tests through vscode and a instance of vscode opens up. But if I want to do normal unit tests against code that has even a single reference to vscode I am not able to do so due to https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/6586. There are several workarounds:

* stick with integration tests (slow, not usable with test explorer UI, and not really usable with command line either†)
* _completely_ extract out your logic to not reference vscode at all. Easier said than done. See https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-wordcount/issues/5#issuecomment-171050759
* mock require to return a mocked vscode (see https://github.com/rokucommunity/vscode-brightscript-language/blob/master/src/BrightScriptCommands.spec.ts)

None of these workarounds are ideal. As @georgejecook pointed out "it seems most people (judging by github repos) simply don’t do a lot of testing". Making it easier to write unit tests would encourage extension authors to do more testing, thereby decreasing bugs and making users and authors happier.

† tests ran from command line can't be run while vscode is opened :(

title: Ability to use variables in prefix and description in a snippet
body:
Hey, 

I think it could be cool if we were also able to use variables in the prefix and description of a snippet. I see this could be a good amount of work for just a little advantage.. This is more of a feature suggestion/idea than a feature request :)

What we have now:
```js
"Update Resource Resolver": {
        "prefix": "updateResource()",
        "body": [
            "update${TM_FILENAME_BASE}() {}",
        ],
        "description": "Resolver for creating a resource"
    },
```
Suggested: 
```js
"Update Resource Resolver": {
        "prefix": "update${TM_FILENAME_BASE}",
        "body": [
            "update${TM_FILENAME_BASE}() {}",
        ],
        "description": "Resolver for creating a ${TM_FILENAME_BASE}"
    },
```

title: Markdown file preview on side, cannot find currently opened but unfocused source tab
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.39.1
- OS Version: Fedora 30

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a markdown file
2. Open the Mardown preview on the side (<kbd>Ctrl+k v</kbd>).  
This opens a Markdow preview tab, in a new tabs group at the right of the window.
3. Give the focus to the left tabs group, by clicking inside the markdow file (source)
4. Open another file  (<kbd>Ctrl+o</kbd>).  
This opens a new tab in the left tabs group.
5. Double-click on a line of text in the Markdown preview

This opens a new tab, in the right tabs group, to show the Markdow source.
It should have focused the existing tab, in the left tabs group.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: **Yes**

title: Markdown link on local files with spaces
body:
Issue Type: Bug Hi, I noticed a difference in the behavior of links within _spaces_ or "_" in the name. link 1: ``[Config]()`` ("_") link 2: ``[Config]()`` (" ") When I am on the preview of README.md and I click the link 1 it opens in "preview", so I can navigate back and forth like I'm on a website. title: Variadic Expansion operator ... causes incorrect syntax highlight
Only one line of stdout is displayed when running a task
body:
Issue Type: Bug **Issue:** VS Code task that run `.bat` file shows only first line of script stdout in terminal. ___ I have a `.bat` file with following content: ``` @echo off echo Generating GUI objects pyuic5 ui/gui.ui -o gui.py pyuic5 ui/serial_setup_dialog.ui -o serial_setup_dialog.py echo Generating resources pyrcc5 images/icons.qrc -o icons_rc.py echo Done. ``` Running this file produces folowing output: ``` Generating GUI objects Generating resources Done. ``` ___ Then I have a VS Code task, that runs this `.bat` file: ``` "label": "ui -> py", "type": "process", "command": "generatePyFromUi.bat" ``` On task execution, this is what I get in terminal output (PowerShell or cmd.exe): ``` > Executing task in folder SerialTool: D:\Stromarija\GIT\SerialTool\src\gui\generatePyFromUi.bat < Generating GUI objects Terminal will be reused by tasks, press any key to close it. ``` Where are `Generating resources` and `Done.` lines? title: MacOS Catalina breaks update check due to permissions check

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
- VSCode Version: 1.37.1
- OS Version: MacOS 10.15

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Check for updates

Result:

A popup:
 
    Could not create temporary directory: Permission denied
    Source: Update service

I thought I'd work around this by adding Code in the Full Disk Access permission set but it seems you can't add apps there; the "+" is grayed out. Presumably there is some metadata needed on Mac to request permissions.

title: [Snap] Opening external links does not work, results in high cpu utilization
body:
Trying to open external links does not launch the web browser, instead it seems that an infinite number of kde-open5 instances are being spawned and killed which results in very high CPU utilization.

This issue affects versions 1.39.1 and 1.40 Insiders installed from snap store. The `.tar.gz` version works fine.

OS Info:

```
Kernel: 5.3.5-1-MANJARO x86_64 bits: 64 Desktop: KDE Plasma 5.16.5 Distro: Manjaro Linux
```

Affected Code versions:
```
$snap list
Name           Version   Rev   Tracking  Publisher   Notes

Version: 1.40.0-insider

Electron: 6.0.12
Chrome: 76.0.3809.146
Node.js: 12.4.0
V8: 7.6.303.31-electron.0
OS: Linux x64 5.3.5-1-MANJARO snap

Version: 1.39.1
```

title: Huge memory leak after update to 1.39.1 from 1.38.0 with Rust RLS on Linux
body: RLS on Linux is already very buggy and causes memory leak, but it stabilizes after eating around 1GB, but today after I updated VSCode to 1.39.1, now VSCode itself, namely `code /BIN_HOME/visual-studio-code/resources/app/out/bootstrap-fork --type=watcherService` component eats more RAM on each file save until the system totally freezes. I am not sure whether something changed in this component in 1.39 release. Downgrading solves the problem, also note that `rls-vscode` extension hasn't been updated for a while so it's not the extension's problem.

title: Support for RHEL 8 in FIPS mode
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.39.1
- OS Version: RHEL 8 (Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Enable FIPS in RHEL 8
2. Attempt to install VS Code

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: n/a


Most likely causes:
* VS Code may not officially support RHEL 8
* VS Code's RPM uses a non-FIPS algorithm for the per-file digest and other cryptographic operations, most likely MD5.


```
[root@rhel8 ~]# dnf install code
Updating Subscription Management repositories.
Dependencies resolved.
==========================================================================================================================================================================
 Package                             Arch                                  Version                                              Repository                           Size
==========================================================================================================================================================================
Installing:
 code                                x86_64                                1.39.1-1570750844.el7                                code                                 77 M

Transaction Summary
==========================================================================================================================================================================
Install  1 Package

Total download size: 77 M
Installed size: 77 M
Is this ok [y/N]: y
Downloading Packages:
code-1.39.1-1570750844.el7.x86_64.rpm                                                                                                     5.6 MB/s |  77 MB     00:13    
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Total                                                                                                                                     5.6 MB/s |  77 MB     00:13     
Running transaction check
Transaction check succeeded.
Running transaction test
The downloaded packages were saved in cache until the next successful transaction.
You can remove cached packages by executing 'dnf clean packages'.
Error: Transaction check error:
  package code-1.39.1-1570750844.el7.x86_64 does not verify: no digest

Error Summary
-------------
```

Workaround (with RPM in current directory):
```
[root@rhel8 ~]# rpm --nofiledigest --nodigest --install code-1.39.1-1570750844.el7.x86_64.rpm
```

title: Nonstop "Initializing JS/TS language features" if you only open interactive playground
body:
Issue Type: Bug Summary: When installing on Catalina, MacOS gives warnings about being unable to open, JS/TS features don't fully initialize, and Typescript commands aren't available. 1. Brand new install of VS Code on MacOS Catalina. 2. Try to open VS. Get an error. 3. Open via menu, click `Open` on prompt 2. Go to the Interactive Playground 3. "Initializing JS/TS language features" shows at the bottom and never goes away 4. Look in the `Errors and Warnings` embedded editor on the Interactive Playground. No errors or warnings are highlighted (or showing anywhere else). I also followed the steps from #82130, but the `Typescript:` commands aren't available, so I couldn't retrieve the logs. This was just downloaded, dragged to Applications, and started. No other configurations or updates were made. I did uninstall, clear settings, and reinstall just to be sure, but it still didn't work. ## Screenshots: When first opening VS Code: There's an option to choose "Open" from Finder: This brings up this dialog, which enables it to be opened: The Interactive Playground (note the spinning `Initializing JS/TS language features` status at the bottom and the complete lack of error/warning highlighting: ![](https://cld.wthms.co/SO5Pyt+) Image Link: https://cld.wthms.co/SO5Pyt I did set `"typescript.tsserver.log": "verbose"`: However, after restarting and going back into Interactive Playground, I found that there's no `Typescript:` commands available: ![](https://cld.wthms.co/jq4W4A+) Image Link: https://cld.wthms.co/jq4W4A VS Code version: Code 1.39.1 (88f15d17dca836346e787762685a40bb5cce75a8, 2019-10-10T23:35:11.314Z) OS version: Darwin x64 19.0.0

title: Find in Folder includes all folders upon search on named folder in workspace
body:
Issue Type: Bug 1. Create a workspace add the following folder, plus couple of other folders ``` //... { "path": "C:\\Users\\...\\folder1", }, { "path": "C:\\Users\\...\\folderNamed", "name": "folderNamed (Special Folder)" }, { "path": "C:\\Users\\...\\folder2", } //... ``` 2. go to explorer view tab 3. create same file with `lorem-ipsum` text in all the folders 4. right click on the `folderNamed (Special Folder)` 5. click on `File in Folder...` 6. ensure that **files to include** set as `./folderNamed (Special Folder)` 7. type `lorem` in the folder into the **Search** box 8. you will see that it retrieves from **folder1** and **folder2** too where it should only retrieve from `folderNamed (Special Folder)`. behaviour works fine on `folder1` and `folder2` since they are not named. VS Code version: Code 1.39.1 (88f15d17dca836346e787762685a40bb5cce75a8, 2019-10-10T23:31:28.683Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.18362
